title: 111_s253
content: The "Fix Housing First Homebuyer Tax Credit Act" is the short title of the Act. It expands and modifies the homebuyer credit. The "Fix Housing First Homebuyer Tax Credit Act" expands and modifies the homebuyer credit by eliminating the first-time homebuyer requirement. This involves amending subsection (a) of section 36 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 and making conforming amendments to the code. The table of sections for subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended by striking the item relating to section 36 and inserting a new item. Sec. 36 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to change "homebuyer credit" to "home purchase credit." Subsection (f) is amended to include recapture of the credit if the taxpayer sells or fails to occupy the purchased residence within 36 months. The tax imposed by this chapter will increase if the taxpayer fails to occupy the purchased residence as a principal residence, with exceptions for death of the taxpayer or involuntary conversion of the residence. The tax consequences for transferring a residence between spouses or incident to divorce are outlined. Paragraph (1) does not apply to such transfers, and the transferee is treated as the transferor for tax purposes. The tax consequences for transferring a residence between spouses or incident to divorce are outlined. Paragraph (1) does not apply to such transfers, and the transferee is treated as the transferor for tax purposes. In the case of a member of the Armed Forces on active duty moving due to a permanent change of station, Paragraph (1) does not apply. For joint returns, half of the credit allowed shall be treated as allowed to each individual. If the tax is increased under this subsection, the taxpayer must file a return. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to extend the application period and modify the credit amount for home purchases. The changes include adjusting dates and amounts related to the tax credit for homebuyers. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to modify income limitations and conforming amendments related to the tax credit for homebuyers. The changes include adjusting percentages and amounts for qualified principal residences. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow taxpayers to transfer a portion of the homebuyer tax credit to others for payment of liabilities related to the purchase of a principal residence, including downpayments and insurance premiums. The IRS allows taxpayers to transfer a portion of the homebuyer tax credit to cover expenses like interest on debt, real property taxes, and funding fees related to the purchase of a principal residence. The Secretary will establish a credit transfer mechanism within 60 days to certify eligibility for the credit. The IRS allows taxpayers to transfer a portion of the homebuyer tax credit for expenses related to purchasing a principal residence. The Secretary will certify eligibility for the credit transfer amount and require notification to the taxpayer within 14 days of receiving the amount. The taxpayer identification number and address of the residence will be included in any issued check, certificate, or voucher. The Secretary may estimate the taxpayer's income for credit transfer purposes based on the previous year's income. The credit transfer amount must be issued within 30 days of application. Interest will be paid on any amount not received within this timeframe. The taxpayer must receive the credit transfer amount within 30 days of application. Interest will be paid on any delayed payments at the overpayment rate established under section 6621. Exceptions apply for failures due to natural disasters or circumstances beyond the Secretary's control. If the transfer amount exceeds the allowable credit, the excess must be recaptured. The taxpayer's tax for the year increases by any excess amount not allowable under subsection (a). Lenders are not required to complete a loan transaction before receiving the credit transfer amount, and they can adjust loan terms due to market changes. The amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allow for a credit for residences financed by state or local bonds. The effective date for these amendments is December 31, 2008, for residences purchased in taxable years ending on or after that date.
